html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /pae̯ˈdiː.koː/, [pae̯ˈd̪iː.koː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /peˈdi.ko/, [pɛˈd̪iː.kɔ]

Etymology 1[edit]

From Ancient Greek παιδικός (paidikós, “belonging to a (beloved) child”).

(Can this(+) etymology be sourced?)

Alternative forms[edit]

  • pēdīcō

Verb[edit]

paedīcō (present infinitive paedīcāre, perfect active paedīcāvī, supine paedīcātum); first conjugation, irregular short imperative

  1. (transitive) I have anal sex with, sodomize, bugger, commit sodomy with
    • c. 84 BCE – 54 BCE, Catullus, Carmina 16.1:
      Pedicabo ego vos et irrumabo
      I will sodomize and facefuck you.

Derived terms[edit]
  • paedīcātor

Etymology 2[edit]

From paedīcō (“sodomize”), from Ancient Greek παιδικός (paidikós, “belonging to a (beloved) child”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • pēdīcō

Noun[edit]

paedīcō m (genitive paedīcōnis); third declension

  1. sodomite, buggerer
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative paedīcō paedīcōnēs
Genitive paedīcōnis paedīcōnum
Dative paedīcōnī paedīcōnibus
Accusative paedīcōnem paedīcōnēs
Ablative paedīcōne paedīcōnibus
Vocative paedīcō paedīcōnēs

References[edit]

  • paedico in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • paedico in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
